author: jojohnson

description.text:
I needed a little more light in the room, and the lightbulbs I had couldÂ´nt be screwed up anywhere. Therefore I got the bright idea to let the printer solve the problem. ;)
Hopefully someone else can use them for bright ideas as well.
They are made to fit the bulb sizes E14 and E27.

No support is neded, 30% infill should be enough but it never hurts to do it entirely solid.
When you play with electricity, you should obviously be as careful as you can put up with (especially when you produce the stuff yourselves).

comments.text: The (US) standard rules for stuff-that-goes-near-hot-electrics nowadays specify a minimum of 90 C. So if you make this with PLA you are pretty much guaranteed a mechanical failure even in an open fixture.
comments.author: paul

comments.text: Thanks for your input, I appreciate it.
comments.author: paul

comments.text: I am not a lighting engineer, only an interested amateur. The question will be whether the low-energy bulb actually has a lower temperature at the base and threads. That would depend on how it's built, where its heat-dissipation parts are and so forth. (Incandescents radiate essentially all their heat from the filament and envelope; cfls and leds radiate a fair chunk from the ballast/driver electronics.)
comments.author: Hatter

title: Nautilus Gears Acrylic laser cut + 3d print

description.text:
My take on the Nautilus Gears... I felt like it needed a bit of colour.
Decided to use acrylic, since I have access to a laser cutter. I recommend using fine grain sand paper on any of the acrylics sharp edges.

I opened the original Nautilus_Gear.STL in PyCam and it reported several invalid triangles. I imported the file into blender and used the decimate modifier to optimize the design. This reduced the file size from 1.7 MB to 173.8 kB, geometry still intact. The less complexity you give the 3d printer / laser cutter / tool of choice, the better. Result was Nautilus_Gear_decimatedHALF.STL The acrylic parts where made on a laser cutter with the Nautilus_Gear.svg, which was generated from the original Nautilus_Gear.STL using slic3r and its Slice to SVG function. It's often quicker to cut 2D parts on a laser printer, than it is to use a 3d printer.

comments.text: How big should the nautilus piece be? What size acrylic did you use?
comments.author: perchik

comments.text: Depends on how big you'd like them :) I believe I used 3mm acrylic, but you can experiment with thicker slices. If you make the gears thicker, then you also need to adjust the bar length. Good luck with the tinkering!
comments.author: perchik

comments.text: Oh, I was mostly asking about the dimensions of the nautilus since the svg has it at .2cm tall ;). I ended up measuring the 3d nautilus in sketchup and found that the longer dimension should be scaled to 72.2mm to fit the bar you provided.
comments.author: Quixotic

comments.text: Great info!
comments.author: perchik

comments.text: WHY ARE THESE FILES 152mB ????????????????????????????? also they scale it at 10% on build plate
comments.author: Taylorsfields

comments.text:
I honestly don't know. I have tried to save them to smaller files, but the file size is about the same each time. It also won't let me save to anything but metric, even though everything I do is in imperial. I think that the program is just bugged, but it very well could be user error. I have been using Cubify Design, it feels close enough to Solidworks, but without the price.
That's actually why I haven't uploaded anything else lately. If there's another program that someone suggests, I may try that and re-upload these. :)

Not everyone has unlimited access to the US nickel, and as an exercise to myself I made this fully parametric coin calibrator in OpenSCAD. Modeled to be virtually identical to its ancestor, you can now measure your favorite nickel alternative coin in your country of choice, and print your local flavor calibrator, ready for the coins in your pocket right now. To limit confusion I added labels to the axis courtesy of tbuser's bitmap fonts. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2054
(place the bitmap.scad file in the same folder to make it work)

Measure your coin.
Render, and print. Follow MrJohn's instructions for the calibration procedure: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11261

title: Lampshade for LED Torch (Forrader/Ultra Fire C8)

description.text:
Some days ago I made this adapter for the gbeam, which is allways mounted.
Then I had to do some works in the dark and needed a lamp. I was to lazy to get a the extension lead, so I took my torch.
But te light was to focused for my need. Next time, I thought, I need some kind of diffuser ... here it is. Hang the torch - or use the litte stand. For the shade itself I remixed the Sleeve for Coffee an Tea Cups.
I added the OpenSCAD code and the FreeCAD files too. You have to print http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1059392 as well to use this design. My adapter with the thread is an extension part for the gbeam, which is an absolutly great thing! Read more about it: http://gbeam.de/

title: Threadless Ball Screw. No More Backlash

description.text:
This is a type of ball screw I read about at least 20 years ago in a technical trade journal. I have also seen it used in some linear actuators. Some advantages of being thread-less is that there is no backlash, no expensive threaded rods, and if you exceed the force threshold the unit simply slips without damage. A perfect combination for 3D printing. 7/6/13 - I have added a picture of a double unit.
7/7/13 - Added bearing mount with 10 deg angle. 4.14 mm per rev.
7/18/13 - Added bearing mount with 623 ZZ bearings and a way to adjust the tension. BOM added to instructions
7/18/13 - Added 623 bearing mount with 38.5 degree bearing angle.
7/23/13 - Added 624 bearing mount with 5 deg angle 8mm shaft
7/27/13 - Added base for 623 bearing mount

BOM: 3) 625 2RS ball bearings. 5 x16 x 5 mm.
3) 5 mm machine screw 16 mm long.
3) 5 mm flat washer
3) 5 mm thin hex nut
1) 8 mm hardened shaft. McMaster Carr 6112K45 or similar
1) printed ball_screw_8mm.stl (bearing mount) optionally print ball_screw_8mm_base.stl Print the ball screw bearing mount at 100% with at least 60% fill. Press three 5 mm thin hex nuts into the pockets on the back side. Place a 625 2RS bearing then a 5 mm flat washer onto the 5 mm screw. Loosely screw all three assemblies into each top side pocket of the bearing mount. Do not tighten them yet. Place the 8 mm hardened shaft through the center hole of the bearing mount and tighten each bearing assembly. The bearings should firmly clamp the hardened shaft so that the shaft will not slide with moderate force but rotate with silky smoothness. If the rod is too tight or too loose reprint the bearing mount at slightly smaller or larger scale and re-assemble until the fit is perfect. If the screws protrude out the back of the bearing mount a washer may be added under the screw head as needed. MINI ADJUSTABLE BOM: 3) 623 ZZ ball bearings. 3 x10 x 4 mm.
3) 3 mm machine screw 12 mm long.
3) 3 mm flat washer
3) 3 mm thin hex nut
1) 8 mm hardened shaft. McMaster Carr 6112K45 or similar
1) printed adjustable_threadless_ball_screw_8mm.stl (bearing mount)

comments.text: What is the force threshold?  What is the acceleration limits.  Im interested in this for cnc machining but I can see where it "slipping" and not having a positive motion at anytime during a machining cycle would be extremely detrimental to any part trying to be produced.  Ive seen where others have used a threaded rod you still get the same type of motion but it also has a positive directional force that cant be "slipped".  If there are formulas for this can you provide them for the threshold and acceleration forces itll work within?

comments.text: Yes that is what I was referring to when referencing the threaded rod (acme or ortherwise) with the same drive pricipal and it having a higher threshold for slipping but the threadless ball screw is about the best idea for linaer motion and I do agree I think its smaller size and lighter weight components lends itself better to 3d printer and even in wood router and plasma tables where the force is more along the the weight of the tool rather than the work load of the tool.  Still never the less a brilliant idea and concept with the right materials and angular contact this can be researched further to adapt it to a lot of motion controls where the primary force isnt trying to make hard material into some form or shape by milling or lathe work. It does bring to light that it could be used for precision location instead of scale glass or otherwise.

comments.text: Great design, works very well, thanks for sharing. One thing I noticed from the one I made (see http://www.thingiverse.com/make:42659http://www.thingiverse.com/mak... ) is that the bearings seem to run on their edges, not on the flat part of the bearing. Is this just an offset problem, or intentional?
comments.author: droftarts

comments.text: This is intentional. If the bearings ran on center, friction would be the only force holding it in place. by running on edge the holding force is much greater due to microscopic deformation and rebound of the hardened surfaces. See comment by thebarron88 or my comment to bwhoward88 below.
comments.author: droftarts

comments.text: I decided to test this. Using jspark's OpenSCAD version as a basis, I printed two different bearing mounts (623 bearings on 10mm hardened rod), one with the bearings running on their centres, one with them on their edge, as per the original. I had 400mm hardened chromed rods, which I ran each bearing back and forth on for 5 minutes, with a drill turning the rod at reasonable speed. Testing grip was a bit arbitrary; I did the preload up as tight as I dared, then pulled on the mount until moved. Findings: Grip on the rod seems proportional to the preload you can put on the bearing. With the bearing that ran on their edges, they ran rough if preload was too high. Grip was good, but gave way sharply. With the bearings that ran on their centres, much higher preload could be applied. Grip on the rod seemed equivalent (though preload had to be higher to achieve this), but seemed to lose grip more progressively. Wear on the rod, even a non-hardened drill rod, was negligable. Conclusion: depends on your application. I think running the bearings on their edges will have a shorter life (though this will depend on the quality of your bearings), and wear the rod they run on, but have slightly better grip. I'm going to set up a test to see how repeatable the accuracy is next.

This is a basic knob I designed to replace a similar one that I broke off a powermatic table saw rip fence.  This knob has a hole in the bottom that a 3/8" threaded rod screws nicely into.  I used vicegrips to hold the rod while screwing it into mine.  The hole is ~1" deep in the knob so size your threaded rod appropriately.

I printed this on a Makerbot with an automated build platform. I found that I needed to print it with a raft given the height. Also the standard raft configuration has a gap between the raft lines which I found allowed the knob to flex too much in the X direction as it got tall. To remedy this I changed the Base infill density to .65 in skeinforge. This makes the raft lines closer together so that they actually touch and form a raft that is more solid in both the X and Y directions. Once printed trim the raft around the edge with scissors and poke out the middle for the rod to go in. I just left the raft material attached other than that. I found that spinning the cut edge of the raft over a small flame smooths it out. Update 9/9/2011 Just uploaded a smooth version that has circles with more segments that you can barely notice when you print it out.

comments.text: Nice knob.  The pink is a funny shade for power tools!  For threading the rod in, it might help to heat up the rod with a heat gun (or even in a toaster oven, if no heat gun), so it melts the plastic a little as it threads in.

description.text:
The original was a good start, and good for a moldable form. This thing represents some simple modifications to the original design to make it more easily printable. There are two primary changes. 1) There is now a central hub that is a cylinder instead of a sphere. This looks interesting, and serves to give a nice anchor point to the design. 2) The part that connects the flanges to the central part is now the same diameter as the widest part of the flange. That eliminates the largest 'overhang' part when printing on its 'side' Other than that, the attached .stl files are for tubing that has a 5/16" inner diameter. It works great with vinyl tubing of that size. Wouldn't it be funny if someone filled those tubes with a hardening epoxy after connecting it into an interesting shape? UPDATE: 07092011
Added a couple more pictures where the hubs are used as semi-rigid joints with vinyl tubing and wood dowels.

1) Download the .stl of your choice
2) Print
or
3) Download the .scad
4) Change parameters (OD in particular) press 'F6', and export to .stl
5) Print
6) Rejoice!

comments.text: Put some liquid in that thing!  :)
comments.author: TrevorLaw

comments.text: another reason I added the cylinder in the middle is to be able to add a 'nipple' to the design.  Then I can attach something to put the liquid in, and have it circulate.  A couple nipples, and a pump and there you have it!
comments.author: TrevorLaw

comments.text: Yeah I thought about that awhile ago and actually bought a pump to do it with oil and water.  Unfortunately the pump was too turbulent and made a nasty foam-like mush.  When I got the time I wanted to get a working Moineau or Peristaltic pump that wouldn't grind the two phases together so much.  Another way to make you can see the liquid is arrange so that it naturally falls to the inlet so you never suck air.  With those regular solids you have I think it will look cool just to put colored water in and turn it over and such.  In a closed circuit the water prefers to stick together as one piece so portions of it can get sucked upwards as the larger mass goes downwards.
comments.author: WilliamAAdams

comments.text: Just tried, ALMOST works but after a few cycles in a little circuit I made the oil slowly slipped away from in between the different colors and they mixed.  It is important that the water fills the   full interior area of the tube or it can drift through the oil as droplets.  Gonna see if I can find some thinner tubing since that could help.
comments.author: TrevorLaw

comments.text: Spent some time on McMaster and other sites and found that it might not be the safest thing health-wise to use mineral oil with PVC tubing on something that's going to be handled by people.  The tubing has lots of plasticizers and it appears mineral oil may be a strong enough nonpolar solvent to take them up from the PVC.  If you query 'PVC' and 'Oil:Mineral' here:
comments.author: TrevorLaw

comments.text: I went down to 6.25mm on my tubing diameter.  It is just barely printable without support on my Up! printer.  A printer that is less aggressive about adding support might actually have an easier time of it.

I was getting affected by ABS fumes so spent a bit of time looking for a good/cheap activated carbon air filter. I decided on this automotive one for under US$8. The only downside was it was bigger than my print bed.
So I needed a holder and something to mount a fan on, and I needed to chop it up to fit on my 155x155 (6") printbed.
So here is the full model and the four cut-up STLs along with the OpenSCAD file. Designed for the above filter and a 120mm fan.
Generally parametric so you can build your own if needed. This was the genesis for my FanLib OpenSCAD Library, see it here, you will need it if you want to edit it, change fan sizes, or adapt to another filter size.
p.s. should also do as a soldering filter, but not tested yet. I've been using this for many months and it has prevented my previous nose/sinus issues. Very happy with results.

Designed for the heavier wedge end down (added weight to stabilise it) and fan outlet at the top. But up to you.
Print the 4 pieces, there is some tension when printing, I had some splitting 1/2 way up some of the prints, just sealed with ABS goo; also had a little lift on one corner... :( good enough to work tho.
Stick together with acetone (for ABS) or you favourite glue.
Bolt on a 120mm fan (I ordered a rubber quite-pc seal),make sure your have the correct air flow direction before you bolt it on :
Insert the filter
Power it on (I run it off the ATX PSU so it is always on when printer is on) and breath...breath-in-the-air...
It is slightly wobbly, due to a corner lift, a couple of rubber bumpers should fix that.
Only had it running for a short while, but I have not noticed fumes, so far so good. I'll report back later.

comments.text:
Hi, what is your experience with your design after half an year? Does it work well?
I'm seeking a solution to get rid of the ABS fumes without a complete enclosure and your design look just like what I was looking for. :-)
comments.author: Stone79

comments.text: p.s. I'm not a high volume printer, so the filter has had low run-time hours, it is still working, but will presumably need to be replaced; I occasionally feel the air flow at the back to make sure it is not clogged, but I have no idea how to tell if the carbon is performing less, other than my nose I suppose.

comments.text: In summary; Works great for me.

description.text: Volant de robinet additionnel pour doigts d'enfants pleins de savon

I created this cell phone mount to hold my phone (Nexus S) while I use it as a GPS or a speaker phone.
It clips to one of the bars on the vent, if the clip doesn't fit, the sketchup model is attached so you can make the modifications. The arms slide out so you can put your cellphone in, then they close and hold the cellphone in place. All the ports are accessible, so you can charge the phone while you drive or plug the headphone jack into your car speakers.
It works well on my Nexus S and my wife's Blackberry.
Enjoy...

• Print all the parts - Clip, top, bottom, left arm and right arm.
  • Put arms in the bottom part of the holder
  • Attached two small elastic bands ( or create one like it did by knotting one end as close to the edge as you can then cutting the rest of the elastic band off).
  • Put lid on (top).
  • Glue the clip onto the back.
  • Attach to car vent

title: Transport screw workaround for wade extruder

description.text:
I don't have a drill-column at my disposal so designed this Dremel attachment to center the 8mm bolt while hobbing.
Pictures say more than words....

Print out the pdf from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9291
Modify the scad file to let the holder fit your Dremel snugly.
You might wanna make the 8mm bolt slot a bit wider to move the Dremel without friction (I heated my holder to bend it a little)
Put your 8mm bolt in a vise.
Put the printed pdf on top (first make a hole in the middle) and fix this paper.
Dremel your 8mm bolt in 16 steps using the indicator.

A simple design that can be a useful bird house. Or you can print 2 back sides and put them together to make a whole raindrop for a cute prop or something.

Ikea inspired assembly. The 2 main pieces are built with hole slots and then you print the pegs that fit them separately.
Snap fit! 1 Back (or 2 if you just want a raindrop prop)
1 Front
1 Perch
8 Pegs
1 string Glue all the pegs into one side and then put glue in the holes of the other side and snap together.
Insert the perch and glue from the back.
Tie a large knot in the string and thread the other end in through the entrance hole and out through the top hole. Hang up and enjoy!

title: Extended Glass Mount for Flashforge Creator Pro

description.text:
These are extender brackets for a 11 1/8" X 6 7/8" (282.57mm x 174.62mm) glass bed plate. With these brackets and a larger glass bed, I was able to get quite a bit more room out of my Flashforge. Also after using a half spool of material getting the correct sizing right -_- 
I had already used the original brackets for my CTC Pro with the same size glass, but the Creator pro has a thicker bed plate. I also had a slightly larger heat plate I had to account for, but it should still work on the default one. As shown in my 4th and 5th pictures, I was able to go from printing 2 base plates to 4 base plates at once, just by doing this upgrade. Doubling my efficiency. Please remember to use a shim for glass bed, and be careful about where your end stops are at when setting up your models for printing in your slicer. It can only go so much farther in the Y direction, be careful. 
Shoutout to Maker111 for the original model, and EagleSeven for doing the measurements for the larger glass plate.

Printer:

Flashforge

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes: Print out and use the existing screws on the corner of your heated bed plate to attach the mounts. Model is aligned correctly, top 2 are for the top left and right corners, same for bottom.

Are you having a bad day? Did the process of trying to unclog your 3D printer nozzle with a drill bit not go according to plan? Have you ever awoken thinking, man that big 12 hour print job must be done by now, only to find that it failed because the filament got stuck around hour 11 and the printer decided to winch itself off the desk and onto the floor? If so, then this model is for you! Because, remember folks, when life gets you down you need to turn that frown upside down, and thats what the happy box is designed to-do. Do you have a problem and cant decide what to do?
No worries, Give the happy box a toss and your problem will no longer make you blue! **** **** Side effects may include: irritability, grumpiness, vengeful rage, hateful spite, glee, and rays of sunshine. The Happy Box is not for everyone. Consult your doctor before use

This model was done in scad and files are included. This model could use some more refinement feel free to modify it if needed. I like to run my printer slow and steady since my print deck has a tendency to dance around a bit so your configurations will vary. I normally print with the following slicer settings Because plastic fusion is a good thing, the smaller the layer is here the better. After all a watertight seal is needed for a water bowl and I would speculate that the better the plastic fusion is here the safer the bowl is for the bird in terms of reducing choking hazards from broken pieces. Layers and Perimeters
Layer height .15
Vertical shells 2
Solid layers 4 top and 2 bottom Infill
Fill Density .25
Infill 1
Solid infill every 6
Fill angle 45
Solid infill threshold area 70 Speed
Perimeters 50
Small perimeters 50
Infill 50
Solid infill 50
Top solid infill 50
Support material 60
Bridges 50
Gap fill 40
Travel 60 Filament and Temperature
I was printing with 1.75mm filament with a bed temperature between 95C to 110C and a hot end temperature of 220.

remixed_from.title: Wanhao duplicator i3 <=V1 - Glass bed XY corner clamp

title: Reinforced Glass Clamp for Prusa I3

description.text:
New: Check my new alternate design for PEI plate here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1430661 Updated new file with a fixed mesh (done with MeshMixer), The file size increased due to the re-meshing but I it looks and loads good in Cura and Craftware, and resolved the gap issue reported in the comments. I tried Netfabb but could not get good results with that. Updated V2 STL (11/30/1025) 1) Increased the length of the clamp bars - This helps to avoid the corner of glass cut with rounded corner finish 2) Added built "pads" to buffer between the glass and the screw. YOU NEED TO PRINT 2 MIRROED CLAMP PAIRS. The pad for the longest screw is manually placed in front of the screw with the thin side of the hole pointing down. I have tested several prints with heated bed set to 110C and these pads (if printed in ABS) will retain pressure without any trouble. Have in mind though I no longer need to remove the glass/PEI board to prepare for print, AND I no longer have to level by bed manually, so remove the pads if they not work for you (i.e. The screw will contact the glass directly). 3) Lowered the holes a bit to better align screw on the glass 4) Adjusted hole sizes to compensate for hole shrinkage. -- You should be able now to use it right away without any part preparation! ================== Based on the original design by austingeorge I have reinforced the clamp to avoid some of the flexing I experienced when pressing the screws against the glass. Also increased the hole size to 3mm, increased the thickness of the hole and lengthened the hole to keep the screw as horizontal as possible (again caused by the flexing).
Print preferably with ABS then use a 1/8" drill bit (or 3mm) to ensure the holes are wide enough to fit the screw after printing.
Also:
  • Optional but advisable: Replaced metal screws with nylon screws so the pressing against the glass is more gentle (I managed to carve a very tiny chip when trying to tighten with the metal screw). These are very easy to cut with any knife so just search Amazon for the longest M3 nylon screw and cut them to the exact length.
    • Update: Another option (instead of using nylon screws) is to cut a small piece of nylon cable tie and place between the screw and the glass. This actually work really well for me since I have glued a PEI plate to the top of my glass.
  • Added the thumbwheels to make it easier to adjust. Totally optional and there are many nice designs in Thingiverse for that. Pick the one you like.
    • From what I have seen so far this design is one of the easiest to implement glass clamps out there. It it keeps the glass really well in place. ...After installing this, auto-bed level, and PEI board for better adhesion (shown in the picture) my printing routine is almost frustration free. Next... filament run-out/broken/stuck monitor with auto-pause....

comments.author: netcat

comments.text: Very sturdy part, thanks for uploading it! The only things I would note (and keep in mind this is the first thing I have printed) are that there are gaps in the STL you uploaded. The end of the clamp that uses the small block is not actually connected to the rest of the body. There is also a gap in the underside below the attached clamp pad. These two items increased my print time by about an hour when printing 4 at a time. I also had trouble printing the attached pad (in ABS). I removed the gaps with blender and reprinted after building an enclosure. They turned out pretty well the second time.

With regards to the gap, this is really interesting. I have not experience the problem. Maybe this is from the slicer settings (trying to correct the model?). Which one did you use? (I did mine with Cura).
I will have a look at the STL. If you use the "Thingviewer" here if does not seem to show the gap.

comments.text: 3dEz, I see the gap too.  I saw it in Repeiter-Host.  Cura has an autofix enabled for default, so that may be why you didn't see it.  I get a warning that the object isn't manifold.  Netfabb should fix it if you want.  Also, thanks for the awesome design!
